titleStmt.title: Event-triggered Output Feedback Control for a Class of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems

affiliation.orgName: State Key Laboratory of Industrial Control Technology
School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering

analytic.title: Event-triggered Output Feedback Control for a Class of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TAC.2018.2823386, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, we investigate the problem of output feedback control for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems with event-triggered input. The considered system contains not only unknown system parameters, but also general nonlinear functions which are not required to be globally Lipschitz, in contrast to most of the existing results in the area. Besides providing two different event-triggered strategies without input-to-state stable (ISS) assumption with respect to the measurement errors, we propose a new way to encode and decode the event-triggered control signals to further decrease the communication rate. With our newly-proposed encoding-decoding mechanism, each time when the triggering event is violated, only one-bit signal, either 1 or 0, is rendered to transmit through the communication channel between the controller and actuator. Clearly, this signal transmission mechanism is more effective and consumes less channel bandwidth. Through Lyapunov analyses, it is proved that the boundedness of all the signals is ensured and the output signal can be regulated to a compact set around zero which is adjustable.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Recently, network control has obtained much attention as it has the advantages in improving control efficiency and reducing the maintenance cost [1]. One key problem brought about by network control is how to address the communication constraints as the network only has limited bandwidth. Eventtriggered control is an effective and well-studied tool which aims to reduce the communication burden while ensuring satisfactory system performance. Compared with traditional sample-data control, event-triggered control renders signals to be transmitted through the communication channel only when certain pre-defined condition is triggered. Thus, it has clear advantages over classical periodic control when taking communication constraints into consideration, see [2]- [3] and references therein for more details.

Up to now, there are many results addressing event-triggered control design problems, see [4]- [12] and references therein for examples. Among all these results, the study of event-triggered control for nonlinear systems is of particular importance as most of the physical systems contain nonlinear dynamics in nature. In [13], an event-triggered scheduling scheme is presented to address the stabilizing control problems on embedded processors. In [14], a new class of event-triggering mechanism that uses an additional internal dynamic variable is presented. In [15], an event-triggered framework for stabilizing nonlinear systems using hybrid system tools is introduced for the first time, and also two different event-triggering conditions are derived. In [16], a methodology for designing decentralized asynchronous event conditions which only depend on the local sensor information is presented. In [17], by taking advantage of the interconnection property of the event-triggered system, a small-gain theorem based tool is used to analyze the event-triggered system. Recently, many interesting results have been reported in event-triggered adaptive control for uncertain networked systems. In [18] and [19], the problem of event-triggered L 1 adaptive control is investigated, while [20] proposes an adaptive control strategy which allows a desirable command performance with the proposed controller exchanging data with the physical system through a real-time network. In [21], the problem of event-triggered control for uncertain strict-feedback nonlinear systems is addressed and a new switching threshold strategy is proposed.

Note that the above results are all based on state feedback control. In [22], the event-triggered control problem for nonlinear systems with partial state and output feedback using ISS small-gain methods is studied and some interesting results are presented. Nevertheless, [22] has several limitations: 1) It needs the measurement error caused by the event-triggering mechanism to satisfy the ISS assumption for the closed-loop system. Such an assumption may not hold even for some affine systems [23]. 2) The studied system is assumed to be exactly known. As a consequence, when system uncertainty is involved, which is very common in practice, the proposed method may not be applicable because the system uncertainty will make the ISS assumption even harder to check. Therefore, the results of event-triggered control with output feedback are still very limited, especially for uncertain nonlinear systems.

Another important issue we address in this paper is to explore whether there are any other ways to decrease the communication rate further, besides employing an eventtriggering mechanism. Typically, when a control signal is obtained in the controller, it needs to be encoded, transmitted and decoded before it is actually applied to the actuator. We would like to point out that, most of the existing results on event-triggered control have never taken the signal encodingdecoding mechanisms into consideration. They simply assume that the event-triggered control signal can be transmitted through the communication channel perfectly, which would demand a huge amount of the limited network bandwidth. In practical implementations, the control signals are first encoded into specified digital numbers, such as 8 bits or 16 bits, and then these bits of numbers are sent through the communication channels. The problem of this mechanism lies in that, if a signal is encoded into 16-bits, while the communication channel can only transmit 8-bits each time in a parallel communication strategy, then this signal needs to be transmitted twice to reach the other end of the communication channel. Clearly, in this case, time delay, data jam, or data package dropout could be involved which may affect the system performance. Besides, even for the serial communication, the more bits a digital number has, the more time it will take. Thus, how to decrease signal transmission bits when an event is triggered is also worth investigating. A pioneer work towards this direction is given in [5], where only the exchange of one bit of information (per controller update) is needed. However, the signal transmission mechanism requires careful design of the event conditions and cannot be applied directly to the considered problem in this paper.

In this paper, we study the problem of output feedback control for a class of strict-feedback nonlinear systems with event-triggered input. Even though the system parameters are totally unknown, the nonlinear functions are known but can be non-globally Lipschitz. Clearly, there is still no solution to this problem. To solve this problem, we first design state observers to estimate the actual system states under the condition that the input signal is event-triggered. Then, we propose two different event-triggered control strategies, namely the fixed threshold strategy and the relative threshold strategy, both of which do not require any ISS assumptions. Moreover, inspired by our proposed event-triggering conditions, we propose a new encoding-decoding strategy to transmit the control signals.

With this new signal transmission scheme, each time the control signal is updated, only one-bit of digital numbers, either 1 or 0, is required to be transmitted through the communication channels. Clearly, this mechanism consumes much less communication channel bandwidth and thus more effective. It is shown that the proposed event-triggered controllers ensure the boundedness of all the closed-loop signals, and the system output signal can be regulated to an adjustable set around zero.

The remaining parts of this paper are organized as follows. Section 2 describes the system model and gives the control objective. Section 3 proposes the event-triggered control design scheme, including the event-triggering mechanism, the design procedure of the controller, as well as the stability analysis of the closed-loop system. In Section 4, we introduce the event-triggered one-bit signal transmission mechanism, while a simulation example is presented in Section 5. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section 6.

div.head: II. PROBLEM DESCRIPTION
div.p: In this paper, we consider a class of uncertain nonlinear systems in equation (1).
div.formula: ẋ = Ax + Φ(y)θ + Ψ(y) + 0 b u, y = x 1 (t)(1)
div.p: where

and x = [x 1 , ..., x n ] T are system states, y is the output, and u is the event-triggered input signal to be designed. θ ∈ R r and b m , ..., b 0 are unknown constants. φ i (y) ∈ R r and ϕ i (y) ∈ R 1 , i = 1, ..., n, are known smooth nonlinear functions.

For system (1), we aim to propose a suitable controller which makes the output signal y = x 1 (t) converge to an adjustable small region around zero while all the other signals are bounded, i.e. to achieve practical stability. Further, we will investigate a new encoding-decoding strategy such that only one-bit of digital numbers, either 1 or 0, is required to transmit the control signals once they are updated. To achieve this control objective, the following two assumptions are made similar to [24] and [26].
Assumption 1: The sign of b m is known. Assumption 2: The relative degree ζ = n -m is known and the system is minimum phase, i.e. the polynomial
div.formula: B(s) = b m s m + • • • + b 1 s + b 0 is Hurwitz.
div.p: Remark 1: System (1) is a widely studied model, see [24]- [26]. Actually, many practical systems can be modeled by (1), including a single-link flexible robot (Page 313 in [26]) and the dynamics of a ship in [27] as examples.

div.head: A. State Estimation Filters
div.p: As the states of the system are not measurable, we need to design state estimators utilizing the output signal y and control signal u. To this end, the filters are designed as follows:
div.formula: ξ = A 0 ξ + ky + Ψ(y) (4) ΞT = A 0 Ξ T + Φ(y) (5) λ = A 0 λ + e n u(6)
div.p: where all the initial conditions of the state signals in ( 4)-( 7) are zero, e n = [0, ..., 0, 1] and
div.formula: e 1 = [1, 0..., 0] T have n elements, k = [k 1 , ..., k n ] T such that all the eigenvalues of A 0 = A - ke T 1
div.p: are in the open left-half plane. Similar to [26], the state estimators are given as
div.formula: x = ξ + Ξ T θ + m i=0 b i ν i .(8)
div.p: By defining = x -x, we have Lemma 1 below: Lemma 1: For system (1), the proposed filters ( 4)-( 7) can guarantee that the state estimation error converges exponentially to zero.
Proof: From ( 4)-( 8) we have
div.formula: ẋ = A 0 x + ky + Φ(y)θ + Ψ(y) + 0 b u.(9)
div.p: Then, we have
Since A 0 is Hurwitz, the state estimation errors converge exponentially to zero.

Remark 2: Different from the existing results in [24]- [26], this paper uses the event-triggered input signal to design the state estimator, see (6). Also note that x in ( 8) is unknown due to unknown system parameters such that it cannot be used to design the controller. Instead, the states of the filters in ( 4)-( 6) are used to design the controller, as shown later.

div.head: B. Intermediate Design Steps
div.p: We derive our controller based on the backstepping approach. To obtain the final control law, some intermediate steps are carried out recursively. Let 2 , υ i,2 , ξ 2 and Ξ 2 denote the second entries of , υ i , ξ and Ξ respectively, and υ m,i denote the ith entry of υ m . Based on the backstepping design procedure in [pp. [31][32][33][34][35][36][37][38]24], we have

where c 2 , σ 2 and d 2 are also positive design parameters and

div.formula: τ i =τ i-1 - ∂α i-1 ∂y wz i ,(28)

div.p: Note that the above recursive procedure gives the intermediate steps to derive the final event-triggered controller. In the following, we are able to design the event-triggered control strategies.

div.head: C. Fixed Threshold Strategy
div.p: In this case, the adaptive controller is given as
div.formula: ǔ(t) = α ζ -ν m,ζ+1 -d tanh z ζ d ε (30) Θ = Γτ ζ -Γσ 2 Θ(31)
div.p: The triggering event is designed as Let τ = t k+1 -t k be the time interval between two consecutive triggering events, similar to [28], we give the definition of semi-global event-separation property below: Definition 1: The controller ( 30)-( 33) has a semi-global event-separation property if τ ≥ t * > 0 for any arbitrarily bounded set of initial conditions.
div.formula: u(t) = ǔ(t k ), ∀t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ) (32) t k+1 = inf{t > t k | |e(t)| ≥ d}, t 1 = 0 (33) in which e(t) = ǔ(t) -u(t)
div.p: we analyze the stability performance of the closedloop system, which is summarized in Theorem 1 below.

Theorem 1: By adopting the event-triggered control strategy (30)-(33), with any given bounded d and an arbitrarily bounded set of initial conditions, all the closed-loop signals of system (1) are bounded and the output signal y will exponentially converge towards an adjustable set around zero. Besides, the proposed controller has a semi-global eventseparation property.
Proof: Consider the following Lyapunov function
div.formula: V ζ = ζ i=1 1 2 z 2 i + 1 2 ΘT Γ -1 Θ + |b m | 2γ ρ2 , (34

) Let c = min{2c 1 , ..., 2c ρ , σ 1 , σ2 λmax(Γ -1 ) } where λ max (Γ -1 ) is the maximum eigenvalue of Γ -1 and ∆ = σ1|bm| 2γ ρ 2 + σ2 2 Θ T Θ + ζ i=1 1 4di sup t≥0 { (t) T (t)} + 0.2785ε, in which sup t≥0 { T (t) (t)} is a constant according to Lemma 1. Then we can obtain Vζ ≤ -cV ζ + ∆ ≤ e -ct V ζ (0) + (∆/c)(1 -e -ct ).(37)
div.p: From (37) we have

By (38) we get V ζ is uniformly bounded. As a result, z i , Θ, ρ and y are also bounded. Since A 0 is Hurwitz, ξ and Ξ are bounded. Now we only need to prove the boundedness of as the boundedness of x follows from the boundedness of , ξ, Ξ, and λ. From ( 6) we obtain
div.formula: where i = 1, •••, n, K(s) = s n +k 1 s n-1 +•••+k n .
div.p: Meanwhile, the system model gives
div.formula: d n y dt n - n i=1 d n-i dt n-i [ϕ i (y) + φ i (y) T θ] = m i=0 b i d i dt i u.(40)
λ i = C(s) B(s)K(s) ( d n y dt n - n i=1 d n-i dt n-i [ϕ i (y) + φ i (y) T θ]).
div.p: where
div.formula: C(s) = s i-1 +k 1 s i-2 +•••+k i-1 . Since ϕ(y) and φ(y) are bounded, from Assumption 2, λ 1 , • • •, λ m+1 are bounded.
div.p: By following a recursive analysis similar to [26], we can obtain that λ i for all i = m + 2, • • •, n are bounded and therefore x is bounded. As a result, we obtain that all the closed-loop signal are bounded. Moreover, from the definition of z 1 , V ζ and (38), we obtain that the output signal y = z 1 satisfies
So y 2 is bounded by a function that converges exponentially towards a compact set

} at a rate of c. Since ∆ is related to the initial conditions of the system through , so is Ω 1 . As can be seen, when the convergence speed c and the system initial conditions are set, the size of 1 can be reduced by decreasing λ max (Γ -1 ), σ1 γ and ε or increasing d i . Now we show that the proposed controller has a semi-global event-separation property, i.e., ∀k ∈ z + , there exists a positive number t * satisfying {t k+1 -t k } ≥ t * . To this end, by recalling e(t) = ǔ(t) -u(t), ∀t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ), we have
div.formula: d dt |e| = d dt (e * e) 1 2 = sign(e) ė ≤ | u|.(42)
div.p: From (30) we obtain that
div.formula: u = αζ -νm,ζ+1 - d2 żζ ε cosh 2 ( z ζ d ε ) .(43)
div.p: From ( 43), u is a continuous function of x i , i = 1, ..., n, ξ, Ξ, λ, Θ and ρ. Since all the above closed-loop signals are globally bounded, | u| must be bounded by a constant ς > 0, i.e. | u| ≤ ς. Since e(t k ) = 0 and lim t→t k+1 e j (t) = d, it is obtained that the lower bound of inter-execution intervals t * must satisfy t * ≥ d ς such that the semi-global event-separation property holds.

Remark 3: Note that u is a nonlinear function of signals including x i , i = 1, ..., n, ξ, Ξ, λ, Θ and ρ, thus the initial conditions of the system must have an effect on the interexecution intervals. As the bounds of system states and initial conditions are unknown, it is not easy to give an explicit expression of ς. However, to exclude the Zeno behavior [31], we only need that ς is bounded and can thus disregard its explicit expression. Yet, how to design the control parameters based on the system initial conditions to obtain longer interexecution intervals is a meaningful future work.

Remark 4: The threshold d has an effect on both the system performance and the inter-execution time intervals. Through simulation investigations, it is found that the relationship among the threshold d, the inter-execution time and the final stabilization error of y is not monotonic when d increases. Also, d cannot be set arbitrarily big as it will enormously increase the control expense. How to find an appropriate d is a nontrivial task which deserves further study. If no event-triggered control is required, by setting d = 0 and d = σ 1 = σ 2 = 0, y will eventually converge to zero.

div.head: D. Relative Threshold Strategy
div.p: that in (33), the event-triggering threshold d is a fixed constant which is not connected with the control signal. In this part, inspired by the idea of [32], we set a varying threshold for the event-triggering condition as shown in (47) below. The advantage of this strategy can be interpreted in the following two aspects, which is also verified in the simulation example in Section 5: 1). When the system states are far away from the origin, the resulted control signal would be very big. In this case, though (47) makes the control coarse because of the big threshold, the system states would still continue to converge to the origin while the time intervals between two triggering events become longer; 2). When the system states are close to the origin, the control signal should also be around zero. Thus, a smaller event-triggering threshold in ( 47) is produced such that more precise control can be applied to the system to get better stabilization performances. For our considered system, the relative threshold control strategy is given as below:
div.formula: ǔ(t) = -(1 + δ)(α ζ -ν m,ζ+1 ) tanh z ζ (α ζ -ν m,ζ+1 ) ε -(1 + δ) d tanh z ζ d ε (44) Θ =Γτ ζ -Γσ 2 Θ (45) u(t) =ǔ(t k ), ∀t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ) (46) t k+1 = inf{t > t k | |e(t)| ≥ δ|u(t)| + d},(47)
div.p: in which ε, σ 2 , 0 < δ < 1, d > 0, and d > d 1-δ are all positive constants. With the above control strategy, we have the following theorem.
Theorem 2: By utilizing the relative threshold control strategy ( 44)-( 47), the results in Theorem 1 still hold.
Proof: From (47), it is obtained that
where |µ 1 (t)| ≤ 1 and |µ 2 (t)| ≤ 1 are time-varying variables.
As a result, we have u(t) = ǔ(t) 1+µ1(t)δ -µ2(t)d 1+µ1(t)δ . Then,
div.formula: Vζ = Vζ-1 + z ζ ( ǔ(t) 1 + µ 1 (t)δ - µ 2 (t)d 1 + µ 1 (t)δ + ν m,ζ+1 -k ζ ν m,1 -αζ-1 ).(49)
div.p: From ( 44) we get
div.formula: z n ǔ ≤ 0. As µ 1 (t) ∈ [-1, 1] and µ 2 (t) ∈ [-1, 1], we have z ζ ǔ 1+µ1(t)δ ≤ zn ǔ 1+δ and µ2(t)d 1+λ1(t)δ
div.p: ≤ d 1-δ . Therefore, substituting (44) and ( 45) into (49), and similar to the analysis in ( 35)-(36) we have
div.formula: Vζ ≤ - ζ i=1 c i z 2 i - σ 1 |b m | 2γ ρ2 + σ 1 |b m | 2γ ρ 2 - σ 2 2 ΘT Θ + σ 2 2 Θ T Θ + ζ i=1 1 4d i T + 0.557ε. (50
div.p: Similar to the proof in Theorem 1, all the closed-loop signals are bounded and the output signal y exponentially converges to the adjustable set
div.formula: Ω 2 = {y|y 2 ≤ 2 × σ 1 |bm | 2γ ρ 2 + σ 2 2 Θ T Θ+ ζ i=1 1 4d i sup t≥0 { (t) T (t)}+0.557ε c
div.p: }. Now we show that the semi-global event-separation property holds. Still, with e = ǔ(t) -u(t), ∀t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ), following the same analysis in Theorem 1, we obtain t * ≥ δ|u(t)|+d κ > 0 in which κ is a positive constant. This completes the proof.
Remark 5: The relative threshold strategy reduces to the fixed threshold strategy when δ = 0, so (44)-(47) can also address the fixed threshold case by simply setting δ = 0.

Remark 6: Note that the sizes of Ω 1 and Ω 2 are very conservative, and the final stabilization error could be considerably smaller than the bounds defined by Ω 1 and Ω 2 . Yet, the explicit expressions of Ω 1 and Ω 2 do provide a guideline to set the design parameters λ max (Γ -1 ), σ 1 , γ, ε and d i . Compared with the fixed threshold strategy, when the output signal y is close to zero, the relative threshold strategy has a smaller threshold for e = ǔ-u leading to that the deviation between u and ǔ is also smaller. In this way, the relative threshold strategy can provide more precise control and guarantee smaller stabilization error. This will be illustrated in the simulation example below.

Remark 7: In [28], the minimum inter-execution intervals for several differen event-triggered scenarios are analyzed, and different event-separation properties subject to disturbances in both state-feedback and output-feedback cases are discussed. However, since the considered system in this paper is nonlinear and uncertain without any ISS assumptions, how to investigate the robust event-separation properties is a non-trivial task and thus needs further study.

IV. ONE-BIT SIGNAL TRANSMISSION Note that the above control scheme does not consider how the control signal u(t) is transmitted from the controller to the actuator. Typically, it needs to be encoded first, transmitted through the communication channel, and then decoded at the decoder side. In the existing results, each time when the control signal u(t) is updated, u(t) needs to be encoded into 8bits or 16-bits digital numbers, and then these digital numbers are transmitted through the network. However, with the help of our proposed event-triggering condition, we are able to design a new encoding-decoding mechanism which only requires onebit signal (either 1 or 0) transmission when u(t) is updated.
Here we only introduce the encoding-decoding mechanism for the relative threshold strategy, as it can be easily extended to the fixed threshold strategy.

div.head: A. Encoder and Decoder Design
div.p: The basic idea of designing the one-bit signal transmission mechanism is inspired by the fact that at each time when the control signal is updated, the measurement error satisfies |e(t)| ≥ δ|u(t)|+d. Based on this observation, we first transmit the initial value of the control signal u(t 0 ) with the traditional encoder-decoder method. Then, supposing t
div.formula: ∈ [t k , t k+1 ), k = 0, 1, 2 • ••, the encoder is designed as below, i = 1, e(t) ≥ δ|u(t)| + d = δ|ǔ(t k )| + d 0, e(t) ≤ -δ|u(t)| -d = -δ|ǔ(t k )| -d(51)
div.p: Therefore, the output of encoder (51), namely i, is transmitted from the controller to the decoder. Accordingly, with the parameters of the triggering conditions and the latest control signal ǔ1 (t k ) stored, the decoder is designed as below:

In summary, the mechanism of the one-bit signal transmission rule is illustrated in Fig. 1 B. Robustness Analysis Now we address the robustness of the one-bit signal transmission rule by considering the following three cases.

1). In the ideal case where the state signals can be measured continuously and precisely, the triggering condition would be = δ|ǔ(t k )| + d. In this case, the decoder (52) would yield the same values as those produced by the controller, i.e. ǔ(t k+1 ) = ǔ1 (t k+1 ). 2). In practice, the state signals are sampled on some time basis, it is more likely that the triggering condition becomes e(t) > δ|ǔ(t k )| + d. In this case, some bounded errors would be resulted between the output of the decoder and controller by taking the one-bit signal transmission rule (51)-(52), i.e. ǔ(t k+1 ) = ǔ1 (t k+1 ) + d1 where d1 is a bounded number which can be either positive or negative. Now we show that, in this case, our proposed control strategy with the one-bit signal transmission rule can still guarantee the system stability.
Note that in this case the system model ( 1) becomes
and the filter ( 6) is changed into
div.formula: λ = A 0 λ + e n ǔ(t).(54)
div.p: with ( 4), (5), and ( 7) remain the same. Lemma 2: For system (53), the proposed filters (4), ( 5), ( 7) and (54) guarantee that the state estimation error is always bounded.
Proof: The state estimation error satisfies

Since A 0 is Hurwitz, and d1 is bounded, it is easy to prove that the state estimation error must be bounded, which completes the proof. Now we are able to give the following proposition. Proposition: In the presence of the bounded error d1 caused by the sensor sampling, the control strategy (44)-( 47) and the one-bit signal transmission rule (51)-( 52) can ensure the results in Theorem 2 if the design parameter d is chosen to satisfy

Proof: From (48) we have ǔ1 (t) = (1 + µ 1 (t)δ)u(t) + µ 2 (t)d -d1 , ∀t ∈ [t k+1 , t k+2 ). As can be seen from the proof in Theorem 2, if we choose the parameter d satisfying (56), the results in Theorem 2 still hold.

3). In the worst case, d1 may grow with time to a very large value which degrades the system performance. How to avoid this case is interesting but challenging, which is still under investigation. In practice, it is reasonable to assume that the error caused by the one-bit signal transmission rule is small for one single transmission, and only after a number of signal transmissions d1 can be accumulated to a large value. To avoid this case, a compromising approach is that a traditional signal transmission rule, which sends the actual control signal to the system, could be utilized to calibrate the output of the decoder, after a number of triggering events have occurred. Therefore, d1 will be reset to zero before it becomes too large. This is illustrated in our simulation example in Section 5.

Remark 8: Note that [5] also adopts a one-bit signal transmission rule, and this rule can be made robust by increasing the design parameter ρ, which is consistent with the results in this paper. However, it is difficult to choose a suitable ρ as it should satisfy a very complicated condition, see (18) in [5]. While in this paper, we present a simple rule (56) to set the design parameters, which makes the controller implementation much easier.

div.head: V. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this part, we illustrate the effectiveness of our proposed control schemes in controlling a ship. Following [27], the dynamics of a ship is modeled as
div.formula: ÿ + Φ ẏ + b 0 (M y 3 + Ly) = b 0 u, (57
div.p: where y is the course angular velocity, u is the event-triggered control input, b 0 = 0, M and L are unknown constants related to the hydrodynamic coefficients and the mass of the ship. By setting
div.formula: x 1 = y, x 2 = ẏ + Φy, θ = [Φ, b 0 M, b 0 L] T , b = [0, b 0 ] T , and Ψ(y) = -y 0 0 0 -y 3 -y
div.p: , system (57) can be transformed into the form of system (1). The control objective is to make the output y = x 1 (t) converge to a bounded set around zero. For simulation studies, the systems parameters are set as Φ = 0.2, b 0 = 1.85, M = 0.12, L = 0.28. In the simulation, we choose k 1 = 3, k 2 = 2, y(0) = 2rad/s, ẏ(0) = 0rad/s 2 , and all the other initial conditions are 0. The other design parameters are set as c 1 = c 2 = 2, d 1 = d 2 = 0.5, Γ = 0.2I, σ 1 = σ 2 = 0.5, γ = 0.5 and ε = 10.

1). We first study the ideal case, in which the states can be measured continuously such that no error is caused by the one-bit signal transmission rule. We consider both the fixed and relative threshold strategies with their parameters chosen as below: (a). Fixed threshold strategy: d = d = 0.5; (b). Relative threshold strategy: δ = 0.5, d = 0.1 and d = 0.3.

Fig. 2 presents the trajectories of y(t), while the eventtriggered control signals for the two strategies are shown in Fig. 3-Fig. 4. Fig. 5 lists the time at which the events is triggered, and it is calculated that the number of triggered events for the fixed and relative threshold strategies in 50 seconds are 100 and 41, respectively. In practice, the bounds of Ω 1 and Ω 2 cannot be computed as they contain unknown system parameters. However, in this simulation example, we can obtain Ω 1 = {y|y ≤ 11} and Ω 2 = {y|y ≤ 13.3} by using the given parameters for simulation study. As can be seen, these bounds are conservative. By comparing the simulation results, it is obtained that the relative threshold strategy not only achieves smaller stabilization error, but also has less triggering events. Therefore, the relative threshold strategy achieve better system performances in stabilization problems.

2). We now examine a practical situation that is discussed in subsection 4.2. In this case, we assume once an event is ] is produced between ǔ(t k+1 ) and ǔ1 (t k+1 ), i.e. ǔ(t k+1 ) = ǔ1 (t k+1 ) + d1 . To avoid that the measurement error is accumulated to a very large value, after the event is triggered for every 5 times, a traditional signal transmission rule is used to transmit ǔ(t k ) to calibrate the output of the decoder. Here we only consider the relative threshold strategy, and the parameters are set as δ = 0.5, d = 0.1 and d = 3.

The system output and control signal are shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7, respectively. From the simulation results, it is observed that though the extra error caused by the sensor sampling is introduced, the stability of the closed-loop system can still be guaranteed. Clearly, this verifies the effectiveness of our proposed control strategy.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
div.p: In this paper, we consider event-triggered output feedback control for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems. Two different event-triggering strategies, namely the fixed threshold strategy and the relative threshold strategy, are proposed. Moreover, a new one-bit signal transmission rule is proposed to additionally decrease communication burden. It is shown that the output signal can exponentially converge to a set around zero while all the other signal are bounded.

There are still some open problems which deserve further study, including how to set an optimal threshold for the event conditions and establish an explicit relationship between the event-triggering threshold, inter-execution time intervals and system performances. Moreover, the robust event-separation properties for uncertain nonlinear systems are also worthy for investigation.
